Week 6

Bhaswar Chakma

09 March 2021

Objectives

  • dplyr::Two table verbs

    • inner_join(); left_join(); right_join(); full_join()
    • bind_rows()

  • dplyr::Grouping

    • rowwise()

Download Projects

*_join()

Join types:

  1. left_join(): return all rows from x, and all columns from x and y. Rows in x with no match in y will have NA values in the new columns. If there are multiple matches between x and y, all combinations of the matches are returned.

  2. right_join(): return all rows from y, and all columns from x and y. Rows in y with no match in x will have NA values in the new columns. If there are multiple matches between x and y, all combinations of the matches are returned.

  3. inner_join(): return all rows from x where there are matching values in y, and all columns from x and y. If there are multiple matches between x and y, all combination of the matches are returned.

  4. full_join(): return all rows and all columns from both x and y. Where there are not matching values, returns NA for the one missing.

Example

library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
df_a1 <- read_excel("data/w6-students.xlsx", sheet = "A1")
df_a2 <- read_excel("data/w6-students.xlsx", sheet = "A2")
  • File: w6-students.xlsx; Sheet: A1
  • df_a1
name age gender assignment1
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10
  • File: w6-students.xlsx; Sheet: A2
  • df_a2

Robin went to Japan; Ranjit attended

name assignment2
Ted Mosby 18
Marshall Eriksen 19
Barney Stinson 12
Lily Aldrin 14
Ranjit 12

LEFT JOIN

# Option 1
left_join(df_a1, df_a2, by = "name") # here "name" is key; You can use, when needed, multiple keys e.g. by = c("id", "name")
# Option 2
df_a1 %>%
  left_join(df_a2, by = "name")
name age gender assignment1 assignment2
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12 NA
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14

RIGHT JOIN

# Option 1
right_join(df_a1, df_a2, by = "name")
# Option 2
df_a1 %>%
  right_join(df_a2, by = "name")
name age gender assignment1 assignment2
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14
Ranjit NA NA NA 12

INNER JOIN

# Option 1
inner_join(df_a1, df_a2, by = "name")
# Option 2
df_a1 %>%
  inner_join(df_a2, by = "name")
name age gender assignment1 assignment2
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14

FULL JOIN

# Option 1
full_join(df_a1, df_a2, by = "name")
# Option 2
df_a1 %>%
  full_join(df_a2, by = "name")
name age gender assignment1 assignment2
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12 NA
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14
Ranjit NA NA NA 12

Taks 1: Prepare data for the next exercise (5 min)

Do not create intermediate objects; Use %>%

  • Step 1: Full join df_a1 and df_a2

  • Step 2: Update Ranjit’s info: age is 70; gender is male (Hint: use case_when())

  • Step 3: Mutate a variable section, which will contain the text “Section 1”

  • Step 4: store the data frame as df_s1

df_s1 <- full_join(df_a1, df_a2, by = "name") %>% 
  mutate(
    # UPDATE AGE
    age = case_when(name == "Ranjit" ~ 70,
                    name != "Ranjit" ~ age),
    # UPDATE GENDER
    gender = case_when(name == "Ranjit" ~ "Male",
                       name != "Ranjit" ~ gender),
    # GENERATE SECTION
    section = "Section 1"
  )
df_s1
name age gender assignment1 assignment2 section
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18 Section 1
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19 Section 1
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12 NA Section 1
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12 Section 1
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14 Section 1
Ranjit 70 Male NA 12 Section 1

Data Structures

Coercion

vocabulary.com: “Coercion is making something happen by force, like when bullies use coercion to make kids give them their lunch money”.

\[logical < integer < double < character\]

# Create Vectors
# Use c() "combine"
v_character <- c("hello", "world")
v_double <- c(2, 99)
v_integer <- c(2L,99L)
v_logical <- c(TRUE, FALSE) # we could also use T and F (not recommended)

# Check Type
> typeof(v_character)
[1] "character"
> typeof(v_double)
[1] "double"
> typeof(v_integer)
[1] "integer"
> typeof(v_logical)
[1] "logical"

Coercion in action:

> typeof(c("Hello", 2.299, 1L, FALSE))
[1] "character"
> 
> typeof(c(2.299, 1L, FALSE))
[1] "double"

What happens when you apply sum() on logical vectors?

> v_grades <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE) # pass = TRUE; fail = FALSE
> sum(v_grades)
[1] 3

Now take the quiz!

bind_rows() & rowwise()

File: w6-students-s2.csv; store it as df_s2

name age gender assignment1 assignment2 section
Sheldon Cooper 47 Male 21 19 Section 2
Leonard Hofstadter 45 Male 19 19 Section 2
Penny Hofstadter 35 Female Absent 15 Section 2
Howard Wolowitz 40 Male 17 18 Section 2
Raj Koothrappali 39 Male 18 10 Section 2

Can you find the mean of assignment1?

  • try mean(df_s2$assignment1)

Have a glimpse of df_s2

glimpse(df_s2)
## Rows: 5
## Columns: 6
## $ name        <chr> "Sheldon Cooper", "Leonard Hofstadter", "Penny Hofstadter"~
## $ age         <dbl> 47, 45, 35, 40, 39
## $ gender      <chr> "Male", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Male"
## $ assignment1 <chr> "21", "19", "Absent", "17", "18"
## $ assignment2 <dbl> 19, 19, 15, 18, 10
## $ section     <chr> "Section 2", "Section 2", "Section 2", "Section 2", "Secti~

Who is the boss?

We need to use as.numeric().

df_s2 <- df_s2 %>%
  mutate(assignment1 = as.numeric(assignment1))
df_s2
name age gender assignment1 assignment2 section
Sheldon Cooper 47 Male 21 19 Section 2
Leonard Hofstadter 45 Male 19 19 Section 2
Penny Hofstadter 35 Female NA 15 Section 2
Howard Wolowitz 40 Male 17 18 Section 2
Raj Koothrappali 39 Male 18 10 Section 2

We can now use mean(df_s2$assignment1) but we must the argument na.rm = TRUE

mean(df_s2$assignment1, na.rm = TRUE)
## [1] 18.75

Problem 1: Bind the rows of df_s1 and df_s2; call it df_all

Solution 1:.

df_all <- bind_rows(df_s1, df_s2)
df_all
name age gender assignment1 assignment2 section
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18 Section 1
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19 Section 1
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12 NA Section 1
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12 Section 1
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14 Section 1
Ranjit 70 Male NA 12 Section 1
Sheldon Cooper 47 Male 21 19 Section 2
Leonard Hofstadter 45 Male 19 19 Section 2
Penny Hofstadter 35 Female NA 15 Section 2
Howard Wolowitz 40 Male 17 18 Section 2
Raj Koothrappali 39 Male 18 10 Section 2

Problem 2: For each student, find average grade

Solution 2:

df_all %>% 
  rowwise() %>% 
  mutate(avg_grade = mean(c(assignment1, assignment2), na.rm = TRUE))
name age gender assignment1 assignment2 section avg_grade
Ted Mosby 46 Male 18 18 Section 1 18.0
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male 19 19 Section 1 19.0
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female 12 NA Section 1 12.0
Barney Stinson 47 Male 8 12 Section 1 10.0
Lily Aldrin 46 Female 10 14 Section 1 12.0
Ranjit 70 Male NA 12 Section 1 12.0
Sheldon Cooper 47 Male 21 19 Section 2 20.0
Leonard Hofstadter 45 Male 19 19 Section 2 19.0
Penny Hofstadter 35 Female NA 15 Section 2 15.0
Howard Wolowitz 40 Male 17 18 Section 2 17.5
Raj Koothrappali 39 Male 18 10 Section 2 14.0

Do not forget to ungroup().
